page.title: 03Sankey Canal and Brook
page.content: Sankey Brook is the main tributary of the River Mersey in the area.In the seventeenth century there were a number of water mills along its course which ground flour,and it was also used as a navigation upto Sankey Bridges. The Sankey Canal replaced this in 1757.The canal was raised a total of 48 feet by eight locks from Sankey Bridges to Hatdock.It was the work of Henry Berry,and carried coal from the mines at Parr and Haydock via the Mersey to Liverpool. Today it is used for leisure purposes,such as,fishing and canoeing,as part of the Sankey Valley Park which has other facilities,such as,picnic areas and is used by visiting school parties.
